title: Assessing and Managing Water Use and Discharges From Aquaculture Facilities

tasks.task: Examine fish and water in aquaculture environments.
subtasks: Observe fish species such as Atlantic salmon, Arctic char, rainbow trout, walleye, saugee, bluegill, tilapia, and shrimp.
Assess water quality parameters, including oxygen levels, temperature, ammonia, and dissolved solids.
Evaluate treatment of waste from fish through aeration and biological processes.
Conduct solids removal from water environments, such as converting organic waste to nitrates.
Manage water treatment systems, such as Recirculating Aquaculture Systems (RAS), to minimize water discharge and maintain oxygen levels.
Monitor and adjust water management practices based on regional climate and species needs.
Check and replace aeration equipment, such as diffusers or agitators, in outdoor ponds and indoor RAS systems.
Inspect and clean solids collection tanks or equipment, if applicable.
Monitor and adjust feeding schedules and amounts to prevent excess solid waste.
Maintain facility infrastructure, such as tanks, pipes, and filtration systems, to ensure proper water flow and waste management.
Adhere to best management practices and wastewater discharge permits, if applicable, to minimize environmental impact.

tasks.task: Operate and manage indoor and outdoor aquaculture systems.
subtasks: Adjust water temperature and lighting in indoor systems for species-specific requirements.
Implement spawning and fry rearing practices for species such as perch or trout.
Monitor water parameters during different seasons and adapt management strategies accordingly, such as increasing aeration in warmer months.
Integrate multiple water treatment steps, including solids removal and biological conversion of ammonia to nitrates, in closed-loop systems.
Explore the use of aquaponic systems, combining fish and plant cultivation in a symbiotic environment.
Implement saltwater aquaculture systems, such as shrimp farming, in appropriate facilities.
Develop and manage mixed-species systems, such as combining coldwater and warmwater fish in the same environment.
